pages:
Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 45160  
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
December 2011 
 
 
 
Establishing Global Research Alliances (Phase 2) 
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB    Asian Development Bank 
  CIDA    Canadian International Development Agency 
  DMC    developing member country 
  ERD    Economics and Research Department 
  TA    technical assistance 
  UBC    University of British Columbia 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (agricultural production and markets, education sector 
development, trade and services, industry and trade sector 
development, public administration, transport management and 
policies) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability), social 
development (human development), environmental sustainability 
(natural resources conservation, environmental policy and 
legislation), capacity development (institutional development) 
Location impact  –  National (medium), regional (high) 
Partnerships  –  Canadian International Development Agency, University of British 
Columbia, and others to be determined 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
   
Team leader  J. Zhuang, Deputy Chief Economist, ERD 
Team members  M. S. Bautista, Senior Economic Advisor, ERD 
  I. Claus, Senior Economist, ERD 
  A. S. Lagman-Martin, Senior Economics Officer, ERD  
  L. Sumulong, Senior Economics Officer, ERD  
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Strategy 2020 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) aims to realize the vision of Asia 
and the Pacific being free of poverty. It focuses on three development agendas: (i) inclusive 
economic  growth,  (ii)  environmentally  sustainable  growth,  and  (iii)  regional  integration.1 In 
support  of  these,  Strategy  2020  identifies  knowledge  solutions  and  the  promotion  of 
partnerships as major drivers of change. In response, the Technical Assistance Strategic Forum 
2008  highlighted  the  need  for  establishing  more  knowledge  partnerships  with  external 
collaborators such as development institutions, research institutes, and private and civil society 
organizations. The priorities of the Economics and Research Department (ERD) for 2010−2012 
also identify the establishment of external research partnerships as a key initiative in improving 
ERD’s  efficiency  and  effectiveness.  These  partnerships  will  be  expanded  under  ERD’s 
proposed strategic initiatives for 2012–2014. 
 
2.  In  April  2010,  the  ADB  President  approved  research  and  development  technical 
assistance  (TA)  for  Establishing  Global  Research  Alliances.2 The  TA  supported  research 
partnerships  with  the  National  School  of  Development  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China, 
Harvard  University,  and  the  Center  for  Economic  Performance  of  the  London  School  of 
Economics for studies relating to rebalancing and sustaining growth in the People’s Republic of 
China, and human capital and economic development in Asia. Building on the success of these 
partnerships, the current TA aims to support alliances with reputable research organizations and 
development  institutions  through  the  conduct  of  more  collaborative  studies  on  selected 
development issues that are of critical importance to Asia and the Pacific. The design and 
monitoring framework for the TA is in Appendix 1.3 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  To  become  a knowledge  bank  in  the region, ADB  needs  to  play  a greater role  in 
addressing existing and emerging knowledge gaps in key development issues. In addition, with 
developing Asia becoming increasingly integrated with the global economy and its economic 
influence continuing to grow, the need and demand for an Asian voice and perspectives on 
global issues are also rising. Moreover, many Asian issues, once considered solely regional, are 
now recognized as global issues. As the only multilateral development bank based in Asia and 
the Pacific, ADB has a crucial role to play in supporting the development of such voices and 
perspectives through rigorous and evidence-based research.  
 
4.  The Technical Assistance Strategic Forum identified five priority areas for development 
and research TA during 2009−2011 in support of Strategy 2020: (i) promoting inclusive growth, 
(ii)  addressing  climate  change  for  sustainable  development,  (iii)  facilitating  knowledge  for 
regional integration, (iv) providing support to address increasing commodity prices, and (v) 
understanding demographic changes and implications for urban development. These issues will 
continue to be relevant for the region. As part of medium-term planning under its strategic 
directions, 2012−2014, ERD identified six topics for its research program, in line with priority 
areas set by the Technical Assistance Strategic Forum: (i) inclusive growth; (ii) development of 
south–south economic links;4 (iii) avoidance of the middle-income trap;5 (iv) the role of Asia in a 
                                                
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank 2008−2020. 
Manila. 
2  ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance for Establishing Global Research Alliances. Manila (TA 7514-REG). 
3  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 7 November 2011. 
4 South-south economic links refer to trade or other forms of economic links and cooperation between or among 
developing countries.

2   
globalized  economy;  (v)  the  development  of  resilient  Asian  economies;  and  
(vi) governance in Asia and the Pacific.  
 
5.  To implement the research program, ERD will actively seek to establish alliances with 
respected research institutions and development partners within and outside of the region, 
building on its past success. Such alliances will help ADB (i) pursue its objective of becoming a 
knowledge bank by establishing a wider research network, (ii) access a larger pool of talents 
and a broader range of expertise, (iii) enhance its capacity and improve efficiency in producing 
knowledge solutions and crafting policy options, (iv) disseminate knowledge solutions more 
widely through its partners’ networks and, ultimately, (v) raise the profile of ADB as a knowledge 
institution. 
 
6.  The TA will finance four collaborative studies in line with the broad thrusts of ERD’s 
2012−2014 research program. The first collaborative study will be on the issue of food security, 
which  falls  squarely  under  the  research  area  of  building  resilient  Asian  economies.  Food 
security is critical to the region’s ability to ensure sustainable poverty reduction and inclusive 
economic growth. Population and consumption dynamics are expected to continue to increase 
global  demand  for  food  over  the  next  several  decades.  Coupled  with  continued  global 
commodity price volatility, these dynamics are creating converging pressures and challenges. 
Similarly,  rising food  production  will  increase  pressure  on  ecosystems  and  competition for 
scarce freshwater resources. The region will also be affected by global climate change impacts 
such as changing precipitation patterns and increased flooding. Higher food prices can erode 
the purchasing power of households and undermine recent gains from poverty reduction. Higher 
food prices will mean that very poor people will eat less or lower quality food, thus exacerbating 
the already serious concern for undernourishment of a large part of the region’s population. 
Deterioration in the health status of the poor will further restrict their ability to gain employment 
and income, thus driving them deeper into poverty. 
 
7.  The food security study will be undertaken in partnership with the Canadian International 
Development  Agency  (CIDA)  and  the  University  of  British  Columbia  (UBC).  Discussions 
between ADB, CIDA, and UBC are at an advanced stage. For the other three studies, ERD is 
exploring possible partnerships with regional development banks, development agencies of the 
United Nations system, bilateral development agencies, and think thanks and research institutes. 
Lessons  from  the  Establishing  Global  Research  Alliances  TA  on  the  nature  of  research 
partnerships are incorporated in the design of the TA implementation arrangements. 
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the TA will be more effective policy development and policy making in 
developing Asia toward sustainable and inclusive growth. 
 
9.  The outcome of the TA will be improved understanding of key development challenges 
faced  by  developing  Asia  through  the  implementation  of  four  collaborative  studies,  each 
focusing on one of the following broad areas: (i) inclusive growth, its measurement, and public 
policy;  
                                                                                                                                                       
5 Many  countries,  after  entering  the  middle-income  stage,  experience  significant  growth  slowdown  and  find 
themselves getting caught in what is increasingly known as the ―middle-income trap.‖

3 
(ii) south–south economic links covering trade, investment, and/or knowledge exchange; (iii) the 
middle-income trap, its causes, and policy implications; (iv) the role of Asia in a globalized 
economy, covering trade, investment, and/or economic governance; (v) development of resilient 
Asian  economies,  including  food  security,  resources  constraints,  and  green  growth;  and  
(vi) governance in Asia and the Pacific. The outline of the expected report from the study on 
food  security  is  in  Appendix  2.  The  outlines  of  the  other  studies  will  be  developed  in 
collaboration with research partners during TA implementation. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will finance four collaborative studies with external partners. Each study will 
involve (i) the production of research papers, reports, policy briefs, opinion pieces, and books;  
(ii)  conferences,  seminars,  workshops,  and  multimedia  events  to  discuss  and  disseminate 
research findings; and (iii) roundtable discussions on research findings with officials and policy 
makers from the developing member countries (DMCs). 
 
11.  The purpose of the research study on food security is to increase understanding of, 
synthesize, and articulate key policy challenges and opportunities related to food security in the 
region, as well as to contextualize the role and importance of the region in the global context. 
The study will provide detailed analyses and evidence-based policy recommendations. It will 
cover challenges and opportunities posed by the dynamics in global, regional, and national food 
markets.  The  study  approach  will  be  multidisciplinary—focusing  on  economic,  social,  and 
environmental aspects of food security. On social aspects, the study will look at the impacts of 
food security from the perspective of how different groups are affected, such as by income, 
gender,  and  country.  The  other  three  studies  will  follow  a  similar  approach,  taking  into 
consideration the nature of the study subjects. 
 
12.  Risk and assumptions. The key potential risk is that concerned government agencies 
in the DMCs may not be fully aware of the study findings and as a result their medium-to-long-
term strategies will not benefit from the research findings. To mitigate this risk, ERD will work 
with key agencies in selected DMCs, through regional departments, in the design and conduct 
of  background  studies,  to  ensure  strong  country  ownership.  Another  potential  risk  is  the 
emergence of a global or regional crisis that will shift the focus of development efforts in the 
DMCs away from medium- to long-term priorities to short-term initiatives aimed at tackling the 
crisis. Another risk involves the underutilization of funds or delays in closing the TA if ADB and 
potential partners cannot agree on, or encounter delays in agreeing to, common terms in the 
identification of study areas and division of labor for the other studies. To mitigate this risk, ERD 
will  continue  to  be  proactive  in  firming  up  partnerships.  The  key  assumptions  include  the 
willingness of policy makers to base medium- to long-term policies on systematic and quality 
economic  analysis,  the  availability  of  high-quality  datasets  in  selected  DMCs,  and  the 
agreement of research partners on the terms of collaboration. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The TA, estimated to cost $1.0 million equivalent, will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The  TA  is  expected  to  finance  four 
collaborative studies, with an allocation of about $250,000 each. Actual utilization by each study 
may vary depending on the availability of useful secondary data, complexity of the issues to be 
addressed by the studies, and required technical expertise. Details of the cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 3.

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA, which will be managed by the Office of the 
Chief Economist in ERD. The studies will be implemented by designated ERD staff, in close 
consultation with other ADB departments, such as the Regional and Sustainable Development 
Department,  Strategy  and  Policy  Department,  and  regional  departments;  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank Institute, as necessary, to ensure that the upcoming studies are policy 
relevant  and  to  avoid  duplications  within  ADB.  A  steering  committee  comprising  the  ERD 
management team will provide strategic oversight, including on the selection of research topics. 
The steering committee will meet as often as necessary to ensure smooth and timely  TA 
implementation. 
 
15.  The food security study will be undertaken in collaboration with CIDA and UBC in a 
manner similar to parallel cofinancing, i.e., work and responsibilities are divided among the 
partners, which will control and allocate their own resources. The TA will finance 11 of the  
16 background papers for the study. A synthesis report will be prepared jointly by ADB, CIDA, 
and UBC. Two workshops will be organized under the study, one by ADB and the other by CIDA, 
with each partner financing the participation of their respective consultants or resource persons 
in the workshops. The TA will finance all costs associated with the study’s publication and 
ADB’s own dissemination activities.  
 
16.  For the other three studies, a similar approach will be followed if the partner is a regional 
development bank or development agency. When the partner is a research institute or think 
tank, either the partner will be engaged as a consulting firm, or its research staff members will 
be engaged as individual consultants. For the four studies, the TA will require a total of about  
44 person-months of international and 23 person-months of national consulting services, either 
as individual consultants or through consulting firms. Individual consultants, resource people, 
and/or partner research institutes will be recruited in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the 
Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). Appendix 4 provides the outline 
terms of reference for individual consultants and partner research institutions. These terms of 
reference will be developed further depending on the selected research topics and terms of 
collaboration with the research partners. During implementation, ERD will seek guidance on the 
appropriate selection procedure from the Central Operations Services Office, on a case-by-case 
basis.  
 
17.  Disbursements  under  this  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).  
 
18.  The TA will begin on 1 December 2011 and be completed by 31 March 2014. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Establishing Global Research Alliances (Phase 2), and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

Appendix 2  7 
 
OUTLINE OF THE FINAL REPORT 
 
Food Security in Asia and the Pacific: Key Policy Issues and Options 
 
 
Policy Synthesis 
 
Part I: Regional Context of Food Security in Asia and the Pacific 
 
Part II: Dynamics of the Food Market: Challenges and Constraints 
 
1.  Competing Demand: Food, Feed, and Fuel 
2.  International Price Transmission and Volatility 
3.  Food Price Shocks: Role of Policies, World Markets, and Trade 
4.  International Trade in Food Commodities 
5.  Global and Regional Cooperation for Food Security 
 
Part III: Food, Society, and the Economy 
 
6.  Nutrition: Global Initiatives Directorate 
7.  Impact of Food Price Increase on Poverty 
8.  Distorted Incentives from Input and Output Subsidies 
9.  Role of Social Safety Nets and Food Programs 
10. Macroeconomic Issues 
11. Fiscal Implications of Food Security Policies 
 
Part IV: From Farms to Forks: Structural Constraints Facing the Region 
 
12. Limited and Diminishing Resources and Climate Change 
13. Determinants of Agricultural Production and Productivity Growth Diagnosis 
14. Research and Development Extension Services 
15. Market Connectivity and Value Chains

Appendix 4  9 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
1.  Individual Consultants (international, as required, intermittent) 
1.  Teams of individual consultants will be engaged for a total of 40 person-months to 
undertake  research  on food  security  and  other  topics  to  be  determined. They  will  include 
economists,  social  scientists,  and  environmental  economists  with  well-established  research 
records in development economics in general and the study topics in particular. Under the 
supervision of Asian Development Bank (ADB) staff, the consultants will perform the following 
tasks: 
 
(i)  prepare background and analytical papers on  topics assigned by ADB staff, in 
consultation  with  research  partners,  and  giving  due  consideration  to  gender 
issues; 
(ii)  present  research  findings  and  participate  actively  in  the  inception  and 
consultation workshops; 
(iii)  revise and finalize the papers for publication; 
(iv)  review and provide comments on the papers prepared by other team members, 
as requested;  
(v)  prepare progress reports, as requested; and 
(vi)  assist ADB and partner agencies in disseminating research outcomes of the 
technical assistance (TA), as necessary. 
 
2.  The individual consultants will report to the assigned ADB staff in the Economics and 
Research Department (ERD).  
 
2.  Economics Editor (international, 4 person-months, intermittent) 
 
3.  An economics editor with extensive experience in editing economic publications will be 
engaged to ensure quality of the publications. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the consultant 
will 
 
(i)  review the draft papers and suggest revisions to ensure the chapters form a 
consistent report; 
(ii)  assist in integrating the overall findings and in reflecting these in the subsequent 
publications; and 
(iii)  ensure that edited materials adhere to ADB style and usage, conform to high 
publication standards, and are properly and timely delivered. 
 
  3.  Resource Persons (as required, intermittent) 
 
4.  A number of resource persons, with background as policy makers and/or experts, will be 
engaged to review the draft background papers, reports, and books, and as participants or  
discussants in workshops.

10  Appendix 4 
 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
  1.  Research Assistants (as required, intermittent) 
 
5.  Depending on the needs of the different studies, a number of research assistants with 
backgrounds in economics and strong analytical skills will be engaged to support the study. 
They will also assist in coordinating and organizing the workshops and other events. Under the 
supervision of ADB staff, the research assistants will help 
 
(i)  search relevant literature and provide summaries; 
(ii)  collect, process, and analyze study-related data; 
(iii)  review papers and other outputs from the studies; 
(iv)  prepare presentation materials; 
(v)  prepare various outputs such as reports and books for publication;  
(vi)  with logistics and organization of workshops and other public outreach activities; 
and 
(vii)  with other tasks that may be assigned. 
 
2.  Copy Editor and Graphic and Layout Artist (national, 6 person-months, 
 intermittent) 
 
6.  A copy editor will be engaged to ensure that edited materials adhere to ADB style and 
usage and conform to high publication standards. In addition, a graphic and layout artist will be 
engaged to lay out the text, tables, and charts, and convert the files into the required format for 
publication. The consultants should possess expertise in copy editing and desktop publishing, 
and  preferably  have  extensive  experience  in  similar  assignments  involving  preparation  of 
economic publications. 
 
C.  Partner Research Institution (as required) 
7.  A reputable economic research institution (partner institution) with well-known expertise 
in key economic and development issues in Asia and the Pacific will be engaged to organize 
and  coordinate  the  preparation,  publication,  and  dissemination  of  research  outputs.  In 
consultation with ADB, the partner institution will create a study team comprising economists 
and/or social scientists with proven expertise related to the study areas, as well as engage 
experts from outside the institution to serve as discussants or peer reviewers. 
 
8.  The study team will be headed by a team leader. Under the supervision of the steering 
committee  and  in  close  coordination  with  the  assigned  ADB  staff  in  the  Economics  and 
Research  Department,  the  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for  overall  administration  and 
management of the study, including 
 
(i)  maintaining proper communication with individuals involved in the project (e.g., 
consultants, discussants, and ADB staff);  
(ii)  supervising  the  preparation  and  finalization,  and  ensuring  timely  delivery,  of 
literature and policy reviews, research outlines, and background research papers 
by the study team members; 
(iii)  organizing the inception and finalization workshops and ensuring the participation 
of the study team members and discussants in the workshops;

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB    Asian Development Bank 
  CIDA    Canadian International Development Agency 
  DMC    developing member country 
  ERD    Economics and Research Department 
  TA    technical assistance 
  UBC    University of British Columbia 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Multisector (agricultural production and markets, education sector 
development, trade and services, industry and trade sector 
development, public administration, transport management and 
policies) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability), social 
development (human development), environmental sustainability 
(natural resources conservation, environmental policy and 
legislation), capacity development (institutional development) 
Location impact  –  National (medium), regional (high) 
Partnerships  –  Canadian International Development Agency, University of British 
Columbia, and others to be determined 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B. N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development 
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
   
Team leader  J. Zhuang, Deputy Chief Economist, ERD 
Team members  M. S. Bautista, Senior Economic Advisor, ERD 
  I. Claus, Senior Economist, ERD 
  A. S. Lagman-Martin, Senior Economics Officer, ERD  
  L. Sumulong, Senior Economics Officer, ERD  
 
 
 
 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
